newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel-PLO talks hinge on Jewish settlement.
newsitem.headline: Israel-PLO talks hinge on Jewish settlement.

text.p: A U.S. peace drive faced an uphill battle on Thursday when both Palestinians and Israelis stuck to their positions on a Jewish settlement going up in Arab East Jerusalem.

U.S. Middle East envoy Dennis Ross, on his second rescue mission in a month, met Palestinian President Yasser Arafat in the Gaza Strip after seeing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a second day in Jerusalem.

The Israeli leader said in a statement he hoped a meeting later in the day of Israel's Shin Bet secret security chief Ami Ayalon and U.S. and PLO security officials would lead to a breakthrough in security cooperation.
Israeli-PLO talks broke down two months ago after Netanyahu gave the final go-ahead to build 6,500 houses for Jews on a West Bank hilltop which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war.
Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, secretary-general of the Palestinian Authority, told Israel's Arabic radio the U.S. mission would fail unless it addressed the core issue of Jewish settlements.
He said work had to stop on the East Jerusalem settlement which Israelis call Har Homa on a hill Palestinians know as Jabal Abu Ghneim.
"It is a basic condition and it is not possible to speak of resuming the peace process without halting settlement in Jabal Abu Ghneim," Abdel-Rahman said.
Netanyahu's aide David Bar-Illan vowed not to stop the work.
"We obviously are not going to stop building in the settlements any more than the Palestinians are going to stop building in their towns," Bar-Illan said on Wednesday.
Israel demands the Palestinian Authority crack down on "terror" before resuming talks.
Israeli and Palestinian officials have played down any expectation of a breakthrough during Ross's mission.

Israel has offered to build housing for East Jerusalem Palestinians and to discuss speeding up talks on building a seaport and opening an airport in Gaza. But the Palestinian Authority rejects the offers.
Abdel-Rahman said Jewish settlements divide up both the West Bank and Gaza Strip and make establishing an independent Palestinian state impossible.

He said Ross's mission would "fail before it starts" if the U.S. envoy neglected the settlement matter only to discuss side issues such as raising a quota on Palestinians working in Israel or operating a Gaza airport and seaport.
